courses.description: This course introduces the history of sign language research and how the findings gradually transform our understanding of sign language in human cognition, as well as human interaction in different sociolinguistic contexts. Key concepts to be introduced include sign language and gesture, natural sign language versus manually coded spoken language, sign language and spoken language grammars, deafness and sign language, sign language acquisition, unimodal bilingualism and bimodal bilingualism.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken LING2303 or UGED1997
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Sign Language | A visual-spatial language adopted by members of the Deaf Community in daily interactions. It consists of a grammatical system which reflects universal principles of linguistic organization but which shows differences when compared with the grammar of the society’s spoken language. |
| Deafness and hearing loss | Deafness is a pathological terminology referring to loss of hearing in measurable degrees and types. It has a strong speech or spoken language undertone, interpreted usually in the context of medical intervention. |
| Signing varieties | Signing is a cover term for a wide array of varieties which reflects at the one end of the continuum the grammar of spoken languages and at the other end the grammar of natural sign languages. Examples of signing varieties include natural sign languages, manually coded spoken languages, fingerspelling, cued speech, tactile signing, etc. |
| Sign Language Acquisition | It covers different types of acquisition processes involving sign languages, which may be L1 acquisition of sign languages by deaf or hearing individuals in a monolingual fashion, or bimodal bilingual acquisition of both a sign language and a spoken language in early childhood or entering adulthood. |

courses.description: This course explores the impact of sign linguistics research on the shaping of new directions in education, in particular, the issue of language in education and the benefits of sign language in educating students with diverse abilities. Factors to be covered include society’s perception about minority languages in bilingual education, attitudes towards and use of oral, written as well as the various modes of signing in different educational settings, code choice, code switching and code blending in bimodal bilingual communication, as well as effects of sign language on children’s literacy, cognitive and sociopsychological development.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students completing this course will achieve a basic understanding about:
1. History of sign language in educating deaf students, especially the rise of sign bilingualism as a consequence of sign linguistics research
2. Controversy between oralism and manualism in deaf education
3. Different modes of bilingual education especially the issues surrounding the deployment of two languages in classroom teaching,
4. Latest developments of educating typical and atypical children using a sign bilingual approach
5. Incorporation of specific sign language and gesture in teaching content areas like mathematics, general science, etc.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Sign Language | A visual-spatial language adopted by members of the Deaf Community in daily interactions. It consists of a grammatical system which reflects universal principles of linguistic organization but which shows differences when compared with the grammar of the society’s spoken language. |
| Sign bilingual education | An approach which supports the use of natural sign language in educating deaf students as first language, and the written mode of spoken language as second language. |
| Diverse abilities | Usually referring to individuals in society or educational settings that demonstrate different hearing, intellectual, and sociopsychological abilities |
| Code choice | It refers to the choice of a language code by individuals in communication; it’s a reflection of the instinctive abilities of bilinguals/multilinguals due to their multiple competences |

courses.title: Sign Linguistics I: Phonetics and Phonology
courses.description:
This course presents an overview of the major research findings related to phonetics and phonology in sign language in the past few decades. Topics to be covered include the transcription systems for the formational parameters of individual signs, perceptual and physiological systems underlying the production of signs, markedness in sign language phonology, phonological processes that result in historical changes and lexical variations, as well as different theoretical frameworks that have been put forward to account for the major parameters and syllable structures in sign language phonology.
Prior knowledge of Hong Kong Sign Language is preferable.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students completing this course will be able to do the followings:
1. Identify and transcribe the basic parameters using the Stokoe Notation system
2. Point out the similarities and differences between the Stokoe Notation System and other systems such as Hamburg Notation System and Sign Language Phonetic Annotation system
3. Identify, describe and explain phonological processes that lead to lexical variations and historical changes
4. Articulate the differences and similarities between spoken language and sign language phonology in relation to the two modalities.
5. Discuss the types of linguistic evidence with respect to three basic phonological parameters (i.e. handshape, movement and location) that have been used to motivate sign phonology models, and apply this knowledge in the phonological analysis of other individual sign languages.
6. Apply the concept of “syllable” as it relates to sign language data
7. Acquire basic knowledge of the current issues of sign language phonology and be able to read further literature independently.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Notation Systems for Sign Languages | This unit introduces three notation systems for sign language data: the Stokoe Notation System, the Hamburg Notation System (HamNoSys), and SignWriting. Students will practice transcribing some signs using the Stokoe System. |
| Sign Language Phonetics | Some major findings of articulatory phonetics in sign languages will be discussed. |
| Common Phonological Processes in Sign Languages | This unit presents common phonological processes and changes that have been found in the world’s sign languages. Students will practice how to identify processes that result in historical changes and sociolinguistic variations. |
| Sequentiality vs simultaneity in sign language phonology | This unit presents the evidence that motivates a model of phonology that takes into account the sequential and simultaneous properties of signs. |
| Handshape as a phonological parameter | This unit presents the generalizations that have been made about how handshapes are configured and constrained in sign languages and how phonological models have attempted to account for these patterns. |
| Location as a phonological parameter | This unit looks into the subcategories of locations, their respective characteristics and how they can be represented in phonological models. |
| Movement as a phonological parameter | This unit presents the different types of movements and their characteristics. It also reviews the controversies surrounding the phonological status of movement as an independent category. |
| Sign language syllables | This unit discusses whether syllable-like structures can be found in sign languages and what are the supporting evidence. |
| Issues in acquisition | This unit provides an overview of the major findings in the acquisition of sign language phonology |

courses.subject: BMBL
courses.title: Sign Linguistics II: Morphology and Morpho-syntax
courses.description:
This course provides an overview of the major linguistic issues related to morphology and morpho-syntax in sign linguistics, with particular focus on how sign languages resemble and differ from spoken languages in these grammatical aspects. Areas to be covered include different word classes, word formation strategies, agreement, tense, aspect and modality, classifier constructions, the use of non-manuals at the morphological levels, and lexicalization/grammaticalization of gestures in sign languages.
Prior knowledge of Hong Kong Sign Language is preferable.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students completing this course will achieve a basic understanding of the followings:
1. Sign languages are natural human languages having striking grammatical parallels with spoken languages in terms of morphology and morpho-syntax.
2. Components of sign language lexicon.
3. The role of iconicity in the formation of lexical signs.
4. The simultaneous and sequential nature of different morphological processes in sign languages.
5. Use of classifier constructions as part of the productive lexicon.
6. How non-manuals perform morphological roles.
7. How gestures can be lexicalized and grammaticalized in sign languages.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Word class | Function words vs content words |
| Iconicity | Iconicity at the sub-lexical level |
| Lexicon | Conventional signs, loan signs, character signs and classifier constructions |
| Verb classes | Agreement verbs, plain verbs and spatial verbs |
| Morphological processes | derivation, inflection, compounding, agreement, morphological markers for tense, aspect and modality, classifier constructions |
| Gestures | Co-speech gestures, gestures in signs, lexicalization and grammaticalization |

courses.description:
This course provides an overview of the major linguistic issues related to syntax, semantics and pragmatics in sign linguistics, with particular focus on how sign languages resemble and differ from spoken languages in these grammatical aspects. Areas to be covered include word order of simple sentences, nominal structures and relative clauses, complex sentences involving coordination and subordination, interrogation, negation, constructed actions, metaphors, use of space, lexical semantics, information structure and communicative interactions.
Prior knowledge of Hong Kong Sign Language is preferable.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Sign languages are natural human languages having striking grammatical parallels with spoken languages in terms of syntax, semantics and pragmatics.
2. The different types of sentence types and how their syntactic structures can be analysed.
3. Fundamental semantic and pragmatic concepts in sign languages.

courses.title: Language Acquisition of Deaf Children
courses.description: This course examines how deaf children acquire sign and spoken languages in either a monolingual or a bimodal bilingual fashion. In the Hong Kong context, emphasis is on how deaf children acquire the sound segments, tones, as well as grammar of Cantonese and Mandarin Chinese on the one hand, and the acquisition of Hong Kong Sign Language in the areas of sign phonology, morphology, word order, and classifier constructions on the other. Acquisition studies of other sign languages as reported in the literature will also be covered, to support the premise that the processes of language acquisition as revealed by deaf children are universal.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken LING3205
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topics** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Spoken language acquisition | Levels of description: 1. Speech perception 2. Grammatical knowledge 3. Literacy |
| Sign language acquisition | Levels of description: 1. Phonological knowledge 2. Morphological knowledge 3. Syntactic knowledge 4. Non-manuals |
| Critical Period | It refers to the period during which children are said to be sensitive to linguistic data for language acquisition. Language acquisition beyond this period displays diversity in ultimate attainment. |
| Impoverished Input | Linguistic data that is supposedly sensitive enough to trigger language acquisition is neither perceived nor processed efficiently due to hearing loss. Alternatively, the so-called language data that deaf children are exposed to show intrinsic characteristics that mar sensitive linguistic input. |
| Sign bilingualism vs bimodal bilingualism | Sign Bilingualism refers to a form of education philosophy for the deaf that promotes use of sign language in education to nurture the ‘L1’ acquisition of deaf and hard-of-hearing children. Subsequent inclusion of spoken language in the education process is taken to be supporting L2 acquisition. Bimodal bilingualism has a much stronger linguistic orientation developed within the framework of linguistic and acquisition theories. |

courses.title: Sign Language and the Mind
courses.description:
This course explores the intersection of sign language, cognition, and the brain, providing an in-depth analysis of how visual-gestural languages are processed and understood by the human mind. We will begin by examining the cognitive and neural foundations of language, comparing human language (both spoken and signed) to animal communication systems. From there, we will explore how the brain processes sign language, considering both typical and atypical language development in deaf and hearing signers.
Key topics include sign language acquisition, the impact of linguistic and social disadvantage on language development, and the unique ways in which sign languages use space and visuospatial cognition. We will also investigate metaphor in sign language, sign language production and perception processes, and the relationship between sign language and written language processing.
By the end of the course, students will have a comprehensive understanding of how sign language provides insight into broader questions about language, the mind, and human cognition, while also appreciating the unique ways in which sign languages interact with cognitive processes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

* **Describe** the cognitive and neural bases of sign language and **compare** them with spoken language.
* **Differentiate** human language from animal communication, identifying unique features of spoken and signed languages.
* **Analyze** sign language acquisition in deaf children and the effects of delayed exposure.
* **Illustrate** how signers use space for grammar and **analyze** spatial representation in sign languages.
* **Explain** how sign language and deafness affect visuospatial cognition and **evaluate** related research.
* **Examine** the processes of sign language production and perception, including articulation and recognition.
* **Analyze** how signers process written language and **explain** its cognitive relationship to sign language.
* **Identify** language disorders in deaf signers and **compare** them with those in hearing individuals.
* **Assess** the social, educational, and linguistic challenges faced by deaf individuals and **understand** the strategies to address them.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Sign Language and Cognition | * Overview of sign language as a natural human language. * Key cognitive and neural questions regarding sign language. * Introduction to visual-gestural modality vs. auditory-vocal modality. * The role of sign language in understanding human cognition. |
| Human Language vs. Animal Communication | * Defining language: key features of human language (e.g., arbitrariness, displacement, productivity, duality of patterning). * Comparisons between human language (signed and spoken) and animal communication systems. * The cognitive capacities required for true linguistic communication. |
| Sign Language and the Brain | * Neurological bases of sign language processing. * Comparison of brain regions involved in sign language and spoken language processing. * Neuroimaging studies: how the brain handles visual-gestural language. * Lateralization and neural plasticity in deaf and hearing signers. * The impact of modality on brain organization for language. |
| Language Disorders in Deaf Signers | * Types of language disorders: aphasia, dyslexia, and specific language impairment in signers. * How brain damage affects sign language production and comprehension. * Cross-modal comparisons: language disorders in deaf vs. hearing individuals. * Case studies of language disorders in deaf individuals. * Insights into the neural and cognitive underpinnings of sign language from cases of language disorder. |
| Sign Language Acquisition | * The impact of age of acquisition on cognitive functioning and linguistic proficiency in deaf and hearing signers. * Neural reorganization in response to a visual-gestural language acquisition. * Neural activation patterns in sign language processing across different acquisition groups. |
| Sign Language and Disadvantage | * Linguistic and social disadvantages faced by deaf individuals. * The impact of limited access to sign language (e.g., in educational settings or hearing families). * The impact of limited access to sign language on cognitive and linguistic development. |
| Sign Language and Spatial Representation | * The use of physical space in sign language grammar (e.g., classifiers, agreement, referential space). * Spatial grammar vs. linear grammar in spoken languages. * Sign language structures that exploit three-dimensional space. * The cognitive implications of using space in linguistic structure. * Cross-linguistic comparisons of spatial representation in various sign languages. |
| Sign Language and Visuospatial Cognition | * The relationship between visuospatial cognitive abilities and sign language use. * How deafness and sign language may enhance certain aspects of visuospatial processing. * Studies comparing visuospatial skills of signers and non-signers. * Cognitive advantages of signing in spatial tasks. * The interaction between sign language use and non-linguistic spatial cognition. |
| Sign Language and Metaphor | * The role of metaphor in sign language: iconicity and abstraction. * How sign languages use visual metaphors (e.g., the body as a source of metaphor). * Differences in metaphorical expression between spoken and signed languages. * Cognitive processing of metaphor in sign language. * Theories of metaphor (e.g., conceptual metaphor theory) applied to sign language. |
| Sign Language Production Processes | * Psycholinguistics of sign language production: how signs are planned and articulated. * The stages of sign production: conceptualization, formulation, and articulation. * Motor control and gesture in sign language production. * Common production errors (e.g., slips of the hand) and what they reveal about sign language processing. * Cross-modal comparisons with spoken language production. |
| Sign Language Perception Processes | * The visual processing of sign language: visual recognition of signs and complex movement. * How signers perceive handshapes, locations, and movements. * Time course of sign recognition: from visual input to comprehension. * The impact of modality on perceptual processing (visual vs. auditory). * Perceptual differences between deaf and hearing signers. |
| Sign Language and Written Language Processing | * How deaf signers process written language: bilingualism in sign and written languages. * The relationship between sign language and literacy (challenges and strategies). * Cognitive processes involved in reading for deaf individuals. * Theories of reading development in signers. * The role of sign language in supporting reading skills for deaf individuals. * Metalinguistic awareness in signers and its impact on reading and writing. |

courses.description: This course aims to provide a first introduction to sign interpreting to students with no prior training of the subject. Different modes of interpreting (e.g. sight translation, consecutive interpreting, simultaneous interpreting) and different models of sign language interpreting will be discussed. Discourses commonly found in local sign interpretation will be introduced (e.g. health, education, legal, social work, business and government, etc.). As an international development, the roles of Deaf interpreters to serve a broader purpose of communication are highlighted. Students are expected to be able to compare the development of local sign interpreting to that of Mainland China, Macau, and other countries.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Modes of Interpreting | Sight translation, consecutive interpreting, and simultaneous interpreting serve different purpose in communication access. Sight translation provides instant access of written text to signers. Apart from competing in their time duration of interpreting, consecutive and simultaneous interpreting also differ in terms of its translation production clarity and appropriate use in different discourse. |
| Models of Sign Language Interpreting | Answering the needs of service consumers, sign language interpreting models develop from helper model, machine model, communication facilitator model, bilingual-bicultural model, to nowadays ally model. |
| Discourses and Demands | Different discourses call for different demands and qualifications of interpreters. They have to equip themselves with different knowledge, both encyclopedic and specialized, in order to relay the messages between their service consumers. Interpreters have to be alert to the register choice, as well as the intended and extended meaning implied in different discourses. On top of our everyday languages Hong Kong Sign Language and Cantonese, other languages, like English and Mandarin, might also be a different demand due to the post-colonial status of our city. |
| Deaf Interpreters | Deaf interpreters have been introduced as unimodal interpreters in international conferences and as language expert in regional setting. The widely use of deaf interpreters has become an international trend and providing better access to the service consumers, especially for those who are Deaf-Blind, elderly Deaf, Deaf-plus, Deaf children, and Deaf foreigners. In terms of human rights empowerment, their roles also serve the purpose of Deaf individuals as language models. |

courses.title: Sign Language Research Practicum
courses.description:
This course offers students the opportunity to engage in a hands-on research practicum in the field of sign language linguistics, designed to enhance their metalinguistic awareness and research skills. Under the supervision of a faculty member, students will work with sign language data, gaining practical experience in data annotation, basic analysis, and critical discussion.
Key tasks include:
• Annotating sign language data using ELAN software.
• Conducting a preliminary analysis of the annotated data.
• Delivering a presentation on key insights related to sign language linguistics.
• Submitting a 300-word summary of their analysis and findings, in both English and Hong Kong Sign Language (HKSL) (with the HKSL portion submitted as a video recording).
This course emphasizes practical application of linguistic theory, fostering a deeper understanding of sign language structure and research methodologies.
For Bimodal Bilingual Studies (BMBL) Major students only. Offerings can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of three times.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

* **Analyze sign language data** using professional linguistic annotation software (ELAN) and apply **tagging conventions** specific to sign language corpora.
* Demonstrate a sound understanding of **basic sign language linguistic concepts**, including phonology, morphology, and syntax within a research context.
* Perform a **preliminary linguistic analysis** of annotated sign language data, identifying patterns and drawing insights.
* Critically evaluate sign language data through **metalinguistic reflection**, considering both linguistic theory and empirical evidence.
* Communicate research findings effectively in both **written English** and **HKSL**, tailoring presentations to diverse audiences (academic and non-academic).
* Develop **research and presentation skills** through the preparation and delivery of a clear, concise oral presentation on sign language linguistics.
* Produce a **300-word bilingual summary** (English and HKSL) that synthesizes their analysis and findings, demonstrating clarity and academic rigor.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Topic** | **Contents/fundamental concepts** |
| --- | --- |
| Introduction to Sign Language Research | Overview of sign language linguistics; Introduction to research methodologies used in sign language studies. |
| Using ELAN for Data Annotation | Learning ELAN software and the principles of annotating sign language production data (e.g., glossing, noting non-manual features). |
| Basic Concepts in Sign Language Linguistics | Key concepts such as phonology (handshapes, orientation, location), morphology (classifier systems, inflection), and syntax (word order, topicalization) in sign languages. |
| Data Annotation and Tagging | Hands-on practice annotating a sign language dataset using ELAN; understanding annotation conventions for HKSL. |
| Preliminary Analysis of Sign Language Data | Conducting basic linguistic analyses on annotated data, identifying patterns in sign structure, and understanding variation. |
| Presenting Research Findings | How to organize and deliver a research presentation; techniques for discussing sign language data and linguistic insights clearly. |
| Writing a Research Summary (English and HKSL) | Crafting a concise, 300-word bilingual summary of findings; specific focus on academic writing in English and creating an HKSL video summary. |
| Reflection and Critical Discussion | Engaging in metalinguistic reflection; discussing challenges and findings with peers and instructors in both English and HKSL. |

courses.description: This course expects students to render at least 90 hours of voluntary service to an organization that uses and promotes sign language and bimodal bilingualism. Such an organization may be a social enterprise, a service provider, an NGO or any organization that supports sign language users as their service consumers or staff members. The organization must have a close relationship with the Deaf community. Students wishing to identify an organization on their own for their voluntary service must seek approval from the service learning supervisor beforehand. The programme may offer a certain number of service learning slots each year but interviews are necessary. There will be a service-learning supervisor to guide students in the preparation of the service-learning programme and a manager from the organization to support their involvement during the service learning period. Students are expected to share their experiences with their classmates at the end of the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: BMBL4201
Appropriate placement must be arranged by the student with the assistance and support of the Service Learning Coordinator, the Centre for Sign Linguistics and Deaf Studies, and other appropriate resources.
